Authors:
Shengnan Zhang, Kevin D Hyde, E.B. Gareth Jones,
Ratchadawan Cheewangkoon, Jian-Kui liu
Title:
Additions to Fissuroma and Neoastrosphaeriella from
palms
Keywords:
2 new taxa  Aigialaceae  Dothideomycetes  Phylogeny 
Taxonomy
Abstract:
Recent examination on palm fungi led to the discovery of a
group of fissuroma-like taxa, which share morphological features:
slit-like ascomata, carbonaceous peridium, trabeculate pseudoparaphyses,
cylindric-clavate or obclavate asci and fusiform, septate ascospores.
Multi-gene phylogenetic analyses based on combined ITS, LSU, SSU and
TEF1α sequences data supports the establishment of Fissuroma palmae sp.
nov. and Neoastrosphaeriella phoenicis sp. nov., as well as two new host
records for F. caryotae and N. aquatica from terrestrial palms.
Fissuroma palmae is phylogenetically close to F. caryotae with strong
support, but differs from F. caryotae in the appearance of pale brown
mature ascospores, and the dimensions of asci and ascospores.
Neoastrosphaeriella phoenicis, associate with submerged petioles of
Phoenicis paludosa in mangroves, provided an insight of a new habitat
for the genus Neoastrosphaeriella. The hyaline to pale brown, fusiform,
13-septate, guttulate, verrucose ascospores of N. phoenicis make it
distinct from others. Additional new taxa and their morphological
features, ecological occurence, as well as phylogenetic circumscription
of the genera in Aigialaceae are provided and discussed.
